fields.Title: Quiet Reading with Tara Penry
fields.Description/Abstract:
Wrote and published 49 new essays in 2024, covering author biographies, public criticism, and more. <br>Examples: "She Persisted / The first female columnist in America weathered a long, dark time" (<a href="https://open.substack.com/pub/tarapenry/p/she-persisted?r=1mk0zn&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=false" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://open.substack.com/pub/tarapenry/p/she-persisted?r=1mk0zn&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=false</a>) <br>"She Didn't Mean to Write a Bestseller, or to Change American Minds" (<a href="https://open.substack.com/pub/tarapenry/p/she-didnt-mean-to-write-a-bestseller?r=1mk0zn&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=false" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://open.substack.com/pub/tarapenry/p/she-didnt-mean-to-write-a-bestseller?r=1mk0zn&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=false</a>) <br><br>From the "About" page: "Why Quiet Reading?"
<p><span>Literary criticism is sometimes offered as an argument at a conference table. What if it were practiced like choral singing at evensong? What happens if the responsive reader </span><em>compounds the energy</em><span> of a text that “gets” this human struggle; adds another voice, spreads the song a little farther? </span>Quiet reading is a practice that encourages sympathetic listening and quality relationships. It traces kinships between present and past. ...</p>
